CONCLUSIONS 358 Indications for Further Research BIBLIOGRAPHY 375 iii CHAPTER I INTRODUCTION Statement of the Problem From the reading of Eugene O'Neill's plays and the O'Neill criticism, the strong impression emerged that the role of the father is much more important than has been generally recognized. Upon careful analysis of each play the father seems to emerge as a compelling character, as a unique influence on ether characters, and as one of the important forces that shape the course of the play itself. O'Neill dramatizes his personal relationships. In his plays, the family, especially the father, when combined with other forces, often drives the protagonist to revolt, or to perform some self-destructive act. The only relief from the pressures portrayed seems to be found in dreams or in death. In many of O'Neill's plays, the major influence, more often than not, is the father of the central character. Many of the better critics have praised the strength 1 2 with which the father characters are drawn. In some plays the structure of the play itself is criticized because there is an overbalance of interest in the father character rather than in the central character.^ O'Neill portrays much an­ tagonism and conflict between the father and his children. Emerging more and more as the canon progresses, we discover that aggressive and rebellious impulses against the father seem often alternated with submissive and affirmative im­ pulses toward the father, closely paralleling O'Neill's relationship with his own father. O'Neill seems to have a personal desire to work out his feelings of hostility and to understand his need to escape from the dominating influence, from the awe and the overwhelming admiration for his father, 2 James O'Neill. The portrayal of his own experiences in play after play seems to illustrate a personal striving to 1-See William Jennings Adams, "The Dramatic Structure of the Plays of Eugene O'Neill" (unpublished Ph.D. disserta­ tion, Stanford University, 1956), hereinafter cited as Adams, "Dramatic Structure," and James F. Elrod, "The Struc­ ture of Eugene O'Neill's Serious Drama" (unpublished Ph.D. dissertation, Indiana University, 1959), hereinafter cited as Elrod, "Structure," re Beyond the Horizon. Anna Christie. The Straw. Desire under the Elms. Long Day's Journey into Night, and Moon for the Misbegotten. ^Dr. Philip Weissman, "Eugene O'Neill's Autobio­ graphical Dramas," Journal of the American Psychoanalytical Association. V (July, 1957), 436. understand, to admire, and to reconcile his conflicting feelings toward his own father. An important aspect of some of O'Neill's protago­ nists is their feeling of inadequacy in facing the demands of fatherhood. O'Neill's personal relationships to his own children were ineffective. He suffered a sense of failure and guilt. This portrait of fathers unable to meet the demands of fatherhood appears again and again in the O'Neill canon. There is in the plays a comparison contrasting the demands of the father upon the hero with the demands of fatherhood upon him. There are several reasons, therefore, for selecting the fathers for study. The father represents a repeating and vivid character in the O'Neill canon. Most of his major plays contain a vivid portrayal of father characters. In the second place, there are many similarities amongst the father characters. Fathers have many similar personal characteristics, attitudes, and relationships with their children. It appears, therefore, that O'Neill is able to imagine the father characterization more vividly than many other types of characterization. It also appears that the father is a fundamental part of O'Neill's dramaturgy. In dealing with family relationships, the father is the most influential family member. Repeatedly, then, the way a father and his children interact is portrayed, and the effects of a father upon son or daughter is often an examination of the many ways a father restricts and prevents the fulfillment of his chil­ dren . ^ We discover, therefore, that the fathers in the various plays have similar functions. O'Neill seems to use the father to assist the plotting of his plays. The father has a very definite relationship to the themes. Often the father helps provide the forward movement. It seems that much of the conflict and its further motivating force is provided by the father. The father is often overbearing, or demanding, or manipulative. He is frequently an obstacle to the love fulfillment of the protagonist. He often threatens to deny the aspirations of the protagonist. Despite all this, he seems sincere and well-meaning and follows the dic­ tates of his very nature. The father, therefore, often seems to be the major obstacle in the path of the protago­ nist. The hero, in seeking to find some way to fulfill him­ self and find life-fulfilling forces, is in some way 3Sophus Keith Winther, "O'Neill's Tragic Themes," The Arizona Quarterly. XII, No. 4 (Winter, 1957), 296. 5 4 blocked, inhibited, or put on a wrong track by the father. In addition, we find that the very nature of the protagonist seems to be shaped by the father. He inherits many of his father's characteristics and is deeply influ­ enced psychologically by him. The hero also learns from his father and assimilates the attitudes and personal problems he exemplifies.^ The father seems to be portrayed as a source of bio­ logical continuity. The father-son, birth-death, growth- decay cycle pivots around the father. Life continues and is portrayed as continuing in many plays, in which fathers pass on to their sons, who pass on to their grandchildren, both the attitudes and attributes that shape their existence. ^Thomas P. McDonnell, "O'Neill's Drama of the Psyche," Catholic World. CXCVII (May, 1963), 120-125. 5Sophus Keith Winther, Eugene O'Neill: A Critical Study (New York: Random House, 1934), p. 159. Hereinafter cited as Winther, Euaene O'Neill. Professor Winther poses the question: How much free will does an O'Neill hero have? The father as a determinant of the hero follows this thesis. "O'Neill's strength as a dramatist is emphasized by his de­ terministic philosophy. It makes his tragedies logically sound and emotionally convincing." Richard Dana Skinner opposes this view in Euaene O'Neill: A Poet's Quest (New York: Longmans, Green, 1935), p. 9. "The poet of the in­ dividual soul, torn and warped, perhaps, by the surrounding mass currents, but still supremely the master of its indi­ vidual choice." Thus O'Neill portrays immortality as a biological conti- •4. 6 nuity. Again, as the O'Neill canon progresses, a change in the treatment of the father-child relationship seems to emerge. In most of the early family plays, the subject of the plays seems to be the impact of the father upon his children. In the mature plays, the subject of these plays is a search for self-fulfillment. But in these mature plays, the father, while not being the protagonist in most cases, is a major influence in the course of events. In all the final plays, O'Neill again takes as his subject the father-child relationship. Thus we find O'Neill examining the effects of the father on a protagonist who suffers and 7 ages under the shadow of his parent. The quality of characterization progresses through the O'Neill canon, and the father image seems to become more clear. There appears to be a changing attitude toward the father. A progressive examination of the plays reveals O'Neill developing more and more kindliness and sympathy 6Bryllion Fagin, "O'Neill Contemplates Immortality," The Open Court. XLV (April, 1931), 215. ^John Henry Raleigh, in 0'Neill, ed. by John Gassner (Englewood Cliffs, N. J.: Prentice-Hall, 1964), p. 20. toward the father characters. From this progression, much of O'Neill's personal experience, his attitudes toward life, and his skill in dramaturgy can also be learned, particu­ larly in the father characters. The problem, therefore, became one of abstracting from the O'Neill canon, material about the fathers, then noting what happens and assessing its significance as the canon progresses, then finally comparing these materials with what is known about Eugene and James personally. Limitations of the Study The first limitation is to select plays that have actual father characters. Most of O'Neill's characters make references to their fathers. This is different, however, from the concrete exemplification of the father himself. Although there are many similarities to father characters in the references to fathers, the references are far more gen­ eral and lack specific quality. For this reason, therefore, it was felt that to study the role of actual father charac­ ters would be far more rewarding than to study the refer­ ences to fathers who never appear onstage. This, therefore, is a study of the role of the fathers represented in Eugene O'Neill's plays. It does not concern plays in which fathers are referred to but do not actually appear. Omitted are most of the one-act plays (except Abortion, Warnings, and The Rope), The Emperor Jones. The Hairy Ape. The Fountain, Welded. All God's Chillun Got Wings. Days without End, and The Iceman Cometh. The second important limitation is to exempt char­ acters that may bear a similarity to James O'Neill but have no role as a father in the play. To assume other characters were suggested by O'Neill's own father has indeed been done by the O'Neill critics. That James O'Neill was the model for Jim Harris, the Negro hero of All God's Chillun Got 0 Wings has been assumed by the Gelbs. The Gelbs also point out that Ponce de Leon in The Fountain and Marco Polo in Marco Millions both have many resemblances to James 9 O'Neill. However, neither Jim Harris, Ponce de Leon, nor Marco Polo has any role as a father, and it seems much safer to deal with characters that are used by O'Neill to exem­ plify the father instead of looking for resemblances to O'Neill's own father. A third limitation then suggests itself, but this limitation is a natural one in the examination of the ®Arthur and Barbara Gelb, 0'Neill (New York: Harper and Brothers, 1962), p. 534. ^Ibid.. p. 528. father's role. The size of the role is limited by the part that the father and fatherhood take in each play. The smaller the role the more limited the information about the father. With these limitations stated, then, "a father" is defined as the male character that has a parental relation­ ship to another character in the play. The term "The Fa­ ther" is the male parent of the protagonist. The term "Fatherhood" refers to the relationship of a male parent to his children who are the grandchildren of "The Father." Other distinctions must be made. Different kinds of fathers are portrayed. The term "paternal father" refers to a bio­ logical male parent who procreates offspring. The term "parental father" designates a male parent who, lacking actual paternity, nevertheless maintains a parental rela­ tionship to another character. The term "substitute father" designates a male character who has neither paternity nor parental status, but who nevertheless may take the place, if only briefly, of a male parent. The plays examined were divided into five periods. The first period includes O'Neill's apprentice plays: Abor­ tion , Warnings. Servitude, Rope. Where the Cross Is Made and Gold. The second period includes the early plays Beyond the 10 Horizon. The Straw. Anna Christie. Diff'rent, and The First Man. The third period includes the middle plays: Desire under the Elms. Marco Millions. The Great God Brown, and Lazarus Laughed. The fourth period includes the later plays: Strange Interlude. Dynamo, and Mourning Becomes Electra. The last period includes the final plays: Ah. Wilderness 1. A Touch of the Poet. Long Day's Journey into Night, and A Moon for the Misbegotten. Method of Analysis Because so many of Eugene O'Neill's plays have simi­ larities to his own autobiography or are admitted by O'Neill to be autobiographical, fathers seem to have many character­ istics of O'Neill's father, James, as well as of O'Neill's own fatherhood. Chapter II of the study summarizes the pertinent characteristics of James O'Neill and Eugene O'Neill as fathers. When similarities to these character­ istics appear in the plays, they are referred to in the footnotes. The rest of the study is an analysis of the role of the father in each of the plays, taken in the chronological sequence listed above.In analyzing the role of the ^Several different chronological sequences of the father, the characterization is examined as it emerges in the action of the play. As each situation involving the father is presented by O'Neill, its cause and its effect are considered. As a result, essential motivations and atti­ tudes emerge and are more clearly defined. Following this analysis, the father's real function in the dramatic struc­ ture is considered. How he assists in exposition, in set­ ting up the essential action, in providing essential com­ plications, as a source of conflict, in heightening emo­ tional values, in setting the course of the action, and as a force in the resolution— all become a part of the analysis necessary in meeting the principal objective of this study. plays are available in the literature. The one used in this dissertation is taken from the copyright dates given by Jordan Y. Miller, Eugene O'Neill and the American Critic (London: Archon Books, 1962), pp. 107-131, hereinafter cited as Miller, Eugene O'Neill. However, Gold is out of sequence because it was conceived at the time of Where the Cross Is Made, and in style, form, and treatment properly belongs among the apprentice plays. James had to go to work. At twelve, his family moved to Cincinnati, and his two elder brothers abandoned James, who helped support 2 the rest of the family. Despite touring, James tried to establish a home in New London. He wished to avoid being "provincial" and did his best to suppress his Irish brogue. With fame and for­ tune he tried to become an American gentleman and strove hard for social acceptance in the community of New London. Yet he was proud of his Irish heritage.
